p: Finally, the dichloromethane extract of Cordia gilletii De Wild (Boraginaceae) root barks, medicinal plant from the Democratic Republic of Congo, a plant known for bactericidal activities against pathogenic microorganisms such as E. coli [ 66], was also found to quench the production of pyocyanin, to inhibit the expression of several QS-regulated genes (i.e., lasB, rhlA, lasI, lasR, rhlI, and rhlR; 35%, 40%, 24%, 25%, 52%, and 23% inhibition, respectively) and to reduce biofilm formation (21% inhibition) in P. aeruginosa PAO1 without affecting its viability [ 54].
